metadata.title: Corrosion, Passivation and Wear Behaviors of Electrodeposited Ni-Al2O3-SiC Nano-composite Coatings

sections.text:
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
The effect of the concentration of Al2O3-SiC nano-particles in an electrolyte bath on the structure, micro-hardness, wear resistance, corrosion performance, and passivation behavior of electro-co-deposited Ni-matrix composite coatings was investigated. Structure and texture studies were done by X-ray diffraction. The Vickers micro-hardness and wear resistance of the produced nano-composite coatings were evaluated and compared with the results of the pure Ni coating. The corrosion and passivation behaviors of the prepared coatings were investigated in an acidic 0.5 M Na2SO4 solution by a potentiostat-galvanostat device. It was found that by the nanoparticle incorporation, the crystallographic texture of the Ni-matrix changes and the Ni crystallite size is considerably reduced to the nano-metric range. It was also realized that the microhardness, wear resistance, corrosion performance, and passivation behaviors of the coatings are significantly improved by the incorporation of the Al2O3 and SiC nano-particles into the Nimatrix, provided that the optimum concentration of the nano-particles is utilized in the electrolyte bath.
* Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 917 811 1858; fax: +98 711 735 4520. E-mail addresses: ramini2002@gmail.com
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Keywords: Ni-matrix Nanocomposite Coatings, Electrodeposition, Corrosion, Passivation, Wear

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Particle-reinforced nickel matrix composite coatings exhibit various engineering applications (e.g. automotive and aerospace industries), due to their desirable properties like high corrosion resistance, good toughness, high specific strength, high hardness, and good wear resistance [1-4]. These coatings are produced by the electrodeposition method which is a low-cost, low temperature, normal pressure, flexible, easy-maintenance, and developed technique with industrial applicability [5, 6]. During the electrodeposition process, insoluble particles are suspended in a plating bath and captured in a growing metal film. Typically, reinforcing powders are hard oxides (Al2O3 [7-9], TiO2 [10-12], ZrO2 [13], CeO2 [14]) or carbides (SiC [15-19], WC [20, 21]) which significantly improve micro-hardness, yield strength, tensile strength, wear resistance, and corrosion behavior [4, 15, 17-20].
Recently, the ability to synthesize nano-particles as reinforcing agents has led to the
development of nano-composite coatings with improved and well-controlled properties [22, 23]. Nano-composite coatings generally display superior mechanical, tribological, anti-corrosion and anti-oxidation properties, as compared to pure metal coatings and composite coatings containing micro-sized particles. It is well-known that the improvement of the mentioned properties is mainly dependent upon the size, fraction and distribution of the co-deposited particles in the metallic matrix [24, 25]. The higher percentages and more uniform distribution of the codeposited particles in the metal matrix enhance the properties of the coatings remarkably.
Ni–SiC composite coatings have been extensively studied by researchers [15-19, 26-28],
mainly due to high hardness and Young's modulus, excellent wear resistance, high-temperature oxidation resistance, and low cost of SiC particles. They have successfully been used as a
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
coating to protect the inside parts of cylinders [15], combustion engines, and casting molds [22, 25, 26] against friction. Also, Ni–Al2O3 composite coatings are interesting, owing to their considerably high surface micro-hardness and wear resistance and thermal stability. For instance, by the incorporation of Al2O3 particles into a Ni-matrix, the wear resistance and yield stress of the coating can be noticeably increased in the order of two- and three-fold, respectively [7-9, 28- 30]. Accordingly, taking advantage of Al2O3 and SiC as the reinforcement, it is proposed that a combined improvement of tribological properties, high-temperature oxidation resistance, and thermal stability can be achieved in Ni-Al2O3-SiC composite coatings.
While the effect of the SiC and Al2O3 reinforcements on the properties of Ni-matrix
composites was extensively investigated separately, there are a limited number of reports [31, 32] on the simultaneous effect of the Al2O3 and SiC reinforcements on the properties of Ni-based nano-composite coatings. To the best of our knowledge, no systematic work was done on the corrosion and passivation behavior of these coatings. In this paper, the effect of the particle
concentration in the electrolyte bath on the corrosion performance, passivation behavior, and
wear resistance of Ni–Al2O3–SiC nano-composite coatings prepared by a co-electrodeposition method was investigated.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental Procedures
sections.text:
Al2O3-SiC reinforced Ni-matrix nano-composite coatings were deposited on a steel substrate by a constant current electrodeposition from a typical Watts bath containing the different quantities of Al2O3+SiC nano-particles, wherein the Al2O3:SiC fraction ratio was designated as 1:1. Table 1 lists the bath composition and plating conditions. Prior to the electrodeposition process, the steel plates were mechanically polished to 1000-grit finish, degreased in an HCl solution for 1 min,
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
and then dried in acetone for 5 min. The scanning electron microscopy image of the selected nanocomposite coatings taken from the coating surface are shown in Fig. 1. The images indicate that at the low (Fig. 1 a, 5 g/L) and high (Fig. 1 c, 40 g/L) concentrations of the nanoparticles in the bath, a high level of micro-cracks and micro-pores exists in the coating surface, respectively. However, at the moderate concentration of the nanoparticles in the bath (Fig. 1 b, 20 g/L), the development of a suitable feature with no detectable micro-pore and micro-crack is obvious. These images will support the results section of the present paper, where more details will be published elsewhere.
To determine the structural changes, texture, and crystallite size of the deposits, X-ray
diffraction (XRD, Pananalytical, X’pert Pro MPD) (Cu Kα1 radiation, 40 kV, 40 mA), with a step size of 0.03°, and a counting time of 3 s was utilized. The relative crystallographic textures of the deposited coatings were determined by the calculation of the texture coefficients (TC) of predominant (h k l) peaks in the XRD patterns according to the following equation [33]:
(1)
where n is the number of reflections used in the calculations and I(h k l) and I0(h k l) are the XRD intensities of (h k l) planes in the experimental specimen and standard Ni sample, respectively. In the present study, (111) and (200) planes were considered for texture coefficient calculations (n=2). The crystallite size of the prepared coatings was also estimated from XRD peaks broadening using the Scherrer equation [34]:
(2)
where d is the crystallite size in nm, K is the Scherrer constant (usually assumed to be 1), λ is the wavelength of the Cu Kα radiation (0.154 nm), θ is the angular position of the evaluated XRD peak, and β is the integral breadth of the structurally broadened pattern.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Dry ball-on-disc wear tests were performed at room temperature under a constant applied load
of 0.5 N at a sliding speed of 20 mm/s. The driving distance on the coating surface was about 200 m and the friction coefficient was recorded by using sensitive transducers. A M50 steel ball (Ø 10mm) (DIN 50324 and ASTM G 99-95a) was used as the counter body. After the wear tests, to evaluate the wear mechanism, the morphology of the worn surfaces was observed by a scanning electron microscope (SEM, FEI, Nova Nanosem 430). Also, the Vickers microhardness of the prepared coatings was measured on the cross-section under a 50 g load and 10 s holding time, and the average value of ten measurements was selected as the final values.
The corrosion performance and passivation behavior of the nano-composite coatings were
investigated in a conventional three-electrode cell with a platinum plate as the auxiliary electrode and an Ag/AgCl as the reference electrode. The samples were isolated with epoxy resin and an area of 1 cm 2 was exposed as the working electrode. The measurements were conducted in a 0.5 M Na2SO4 solution at 25 ◦C, using a potentiostat/galvanostat device (Vertex, Ivium Technologies). Prior to the tests, with the addition of a sufficient amount of H2SO4, the pH value of the electrolyte was fixed at 2. Linear polarization tests were performed from −100 mV to
+100 mV vs. the open circuit potential (OCP) at a scan rate of 0.5 mV/s. Then, Tafel curves were established at the sweep rate of 0.1 mV/s. The corrosion potential (Ecorr) and corrosion current density (icorr) of the nano-composite coatings were estimated from the Stern–Geary equation [35] and determined from the intersection of the cathodic and anodic Tafel curves using the Tafel extrapolation method. To investigate the passivation behavior of the prepared composite coatings, the potentiodynamic polarization and cyclic voltammetry were performed on the samples at the sweep rate of 0.05 mV/s. Afterward, passivation parameters including passivation potential (Ep), passivation current density (ip), breakdown potential (Eb), and re-passivation
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
potential (Erp) were estimated. Finally, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted at an applied AC potential of ±5 mV vs. OCP. The employed amplitude of sinusoidal signal was 10 mV, and the frequency range was from 1 MHz to10 mHz. Nyquist and Bode plots were used to describe the corrosion behavior of the nano-composite coatings. The data attained from EIS were fitted and analyzed using IviumSoft 2.231 software.

sections.heading: 3.1. Structural Analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 2 indicates the XRD patterns of the deposited coatings at the various concentrations of the reinforcement ranging from 0 g/L to 40 g/L. As can be observed, the characteristic peaks of the Ni matrix clearly appears in the deposited coatings and the main peaks of Al2O3 and SiC are evident, especially at the moderate concentrations of the reinforcement (e.g. 20 g/L Al2O3+SiC, Fig. 2 b) in the electrolyte bath. That is, the Ni-based composite coatings are successfully deposited on the steel substrate. Comparing the (111) and (200) peaks of the pure Ni coating and those of the composite coatings reveals that in the pure Ni coating with the FCC structure, the (200) and (111) planes are the main diffractions. This suggests that the pure Ni coating is oriented in the (111) and (200) plane directions. This can be correlated with the [100] texture associated with the deposits with the minimum hardness and maximum ductility [16]. As indicated in the figure, with the addition of the nano-particles to the deposition bath, the intensity of the (200) peaks is significantly reduced and the (111) diffraction acts as the main diffraction plane, indicating a random crystallographic texture in the composite coatings. Since the atomic density of the (111) plane is higher than that of the (200) plane in the FCC crystal structure of
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
nickel, the surface energy of the (111) plane is lower than that of the (200) plane [9]. It seems that nickel atoms migrate from the higher-energy (100) planes to the lower-energy (111) planes by the nano-particles incorporation, resulting in the random texture orientation [9]. Table 2 summarizes the results of the texture coefficient calculations of the (200) and (111) reflections in the pure nickel and nickel composite coatings. As can be seen, the (200) texture coefficient of the pure Ni coating is greater than that of the composite coatings, indicating a strong (100) crystallographic texture in the pure Ni coating. However, by the nano-particles incorporation, the (111) texture coefficient for all of the composite coatings is considerably high, indicating a relatively random orientation in the composite coatings and a texture modification from the soft [100] mode to the preferred [211] mode by the particles incorporation [16]. It is very essential to the wear, corrosion and oxidation resistances of the composite coatings.
Moreover, it can be seen that by increasing the reinforcement content in the electrolyte bath,
the broadening of the Ni peaks, particularly (111) diffraction, changes, thereby indicating the reinforcement effect on the crystallite size of the Ni-matrix. It is well known that the Ni-matrix crystallite size is significantly reduced by a more incorporation of nano-particles in the deposited layer [36]. The incorporated Al2O3 and SiC nano-particles can restrain the growth of Ni crystals by increasing the nucleation rate, by retarding the grain growth, and/or by changing the preferred orientations for the grain growth [36]. Fig. 3 illustrates the variation of the Ni crystallite size at the different concentrations of the nano-particles in the electroplating bath. Concerning the figure, by adding the particles to the electrolyte bath, the Ni crystallite size is drastically reduced up to 20 g/L (Al2O3+SiC) and then gradually increased. This is due to the fact that by increasing the concentration of the particles concentration in the deposition bath, the nano-particles fraction
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
in the deposited film is initially increased and after 20 g/L, especially owing to the particle agglomeration [37] and the enhancement of the particle interaction [38, 39], is slowly reduced.

sections.heading: 3.2. Micro-hardness Variations
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the micro-hardness variation of the produced coatings (taken from the cross sections of the coatings) as a function of the concentration of the nano-particulates in the deposition bath. Concerning the results, the micro-hardness variation is in the range of 448-HV. As can be seen, the micro-hardness value of the deposited nickel coatings increases considerably by adding the nano-particles to the deposition bath, which can be attributed to the incorporation of the hard Al2O3-SiC nano-particles into the Ni-matrix, as well as the texture modification of the Ni matrix from the soft [1 0 0] mode to the mixed preferred [2 1 1] mode. Also, by increasing the particles concentration in the bath, because of the enhancement of their fraction in the deposited coating, micro-hardness is initially enhanced and then reaches its maximum value (525 HV) at 20 g/L (Al2O3+SiC). At the higher particles concentrations (e.g. 40 g/L), practically due to the enhancement of the particles agglomeration in the deposition bath [37] and consequently the formation of the micro-pores in the deposited coatings [40-42], a reduction in the micro-hardness value of the composite coatings is gradually observed. The coatings micro-hardness is principally linked to the matrix microstructure and particles properties in the coatings [10]. The particle-strengthening, dispersion strengthening (due to Orowan mechanism) and grain refinement strengthening (from Hall–Petch relationship) are three possible explanations for the increase of the coating micro-hardness by the nano-particles incorporation into the metallic matrix [3, 10, 42]. In the first mechanism, which is related to the particles volume fraction of > 20%, strengthening is achieved due to the matrix deformation constrained by the particles
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
incorporation, where the load is carried by both the matrix and the hard particles [43]. In the dispersion-strengthening, the matrix carries the load and the fine particles (<1µm), with the volume fraction less than 15%, hinder the dislocation movement by forming dislocation pile-ups at grain boundaries [43]. The third mechanism is associated with structural refinement due to the nucleation of minor grains on the surface of embedded particles [44]. The presence of smaller grains obstructs the dislocation motion, resulting in an increase in the coating micro-hardness [40]. In the present work, according to the size and fraction of the incorporated particles, the micro-hardness variations can only be described by the second and third mechanisms. Indeed, by increasing the nano-particulates content in the deposited film, the grain-refining and dispersion strengthening occur and consequently the micro-hardness increases. However, it seems that the enhancement of micro-hardness by increasing the particles concentration from 5 g/L to 20 g/L is predominantly attributed to the Orowan mechanism, rather than grain refinement strengthening, since the nickel-matrix crystallite size of the produced nano-composite coatings is relatively identical ranging from 14 nm to 23 nm.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Worn Surface Observations
sections.text:
Fig. 5 shows the low-magnification SEM images of the worn surfaces of the coatings deposited at 0 g/L (pure Ni), 10 g/L and 20 g/L particle concentration (Al2O3+SiC) in the electrodeposition bath. Concerning the figure, by the incorporation of the Al2O3-SiC particles, the width and depth of wear tracks are progressively reduced, revealing the enhancement of the wear resistance of the deposited layer. As can be seen in Fig. 5 (a), the worn surface of the pure Ni coating is plastically deformed, which is indicative of the poor wear resistance of the coating. By the nanoparticle
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
incorporation into the deposited coatings, the wear grooves on the wear surfaces are beginning to increasingly become intermittent and the wear mechanism transits from adhesive to abrasive, signifying a considerable improvement in the wear resistance of the coating. The existence of scratches parallel to the direction of motion on the composite coatings is the feature of the abrasive wear [19, 45, 46]. In the coatings with the higher nanoparticles contents, e.g. the coating deposited from the electrolyte bath with 20 g/L nano-particles, a very low level of plastic deformation occurs on the coating surface and the abrasive wear is the main wear mechanism. The enhancement of the wear resistance and the modification of the wear mechanism by the particles incorporation into the Ni-matrix can be associated with the dispersion strengthening effect and grain refinement of the Ni matrix [15, 47, 48]. Moreover, a reduction in a direct contact between the nickel matrix and steel ball during sliding can be considered as an important factor for the wear mechanism modification by the particles embedding. Indeed, by a further incorporation of the nano-particles, the load bearing capability is enhanced and the direct metal to metal contact is avoided, provided that the particles distribution in the metal matrix is almost uniform [8, 13, 30, 49].

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Wear Rate and Friction Coefficient Measurements
sections.text:
Fig. 6 demonstrates the variation of the wear rate (Fig. 6 (a)) and friction coefficient (Fig. 6 (b)) of the produced Ni/Al2O3-SiC composite coatings as a function of the reinforcement concentration in the electrolyte bath. As it is obvious, an effective decrease in the sliding wear rate of the coatings is observed by nano-particles incorporation up to 20 g/L. It is attributed to the microhardness enhancement and the wear mechanism alteration by particles incorporation. However, at higher concentrations, it increases significantly due to the microhardness reduction
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
and surface porosities development. Concerning Fig. 6 (b), the nano-particles incorporation resulted in an effective increase in the friction coefficient of the Ni-matrix and by increasing the particles concentration in the deposition bath, the friction coefficient displays an increasing trend. During the sliding wear of the composite coatings, after a short period, because of a stress concentration between the matrix and incorporated nano-particles, the hard nano-particles can be easily pulled out of the Ni-matrix and move along with the steel ball during sliding [41, 50]. This promotes the abrasion wear and increases the friction coefficient due to the abrasive effect. By increasing the particle concentration in the bath, due to the formation of a protruding grain morphology, the coatings surface roughness is increased; also, at the sufficiently high concentrations of the nano-particles (e.g. 25 g/L and 40 g/L), the surface porosity grows, particularly due to the development of agglomerated particles [37] and the enhancement of the particle collision in the deposition bath [38, 39]. These assist the pulled out process during sliding and consequently enhance the friction coefficient.

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Corrosion Potential
sections.text:
To investigate the corrosion and passivation behaviors of the prepared coatings, polarization studies were done in an acidic 0.5 M Na2SO4 solution. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 2 by adding a sufficient amount of high purity (>98%) H2SO4. Fig. 7 shows the potentiodynamic polarization curves of the pure Ni and nano-composite coatings. Apparently, by the particles incorporation, due to the exposure of the under-layer steel surface at micro-crack sites (Fig. 1 (a)) on the coating surface, the corrosion potential of the coating is initially reduced with respect to the pure Ni coating. By a more incorporation of the nano-particles into the Ni-matrix, the open
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
circuit potential of the composite coatings returns to noble directions and reaches its maximum value at the reinforcement concentration of 20 g/L in the electrolyte bath. This can be attributed to the improvement of the coating microstructure and the reduction of surface defects at the sufficiently high fraction of the reinforcement in the composite coatings (Fig. 1 (b)). However, at the high concentrations of the nano-particles in the bath (e.g. 40 g/L Al2O3+SiC), the fraction of micro-pores on the coatings surface increases (Fig. 1 (c)); consequently, the corrosion potential of the deposited coating shifts again to more negative directions.

sections.heading: 3.4.2. Corrosion Current Density
sections.text:
Fig. 8 illustrates the variation of the corrosion current density (icorr) of the prepared coatings as a function of the nano-particles concentration in the electrolyte bath. The results were estimated from the Tafel extrapolation and the linear polarization resistance methods. It can be seen that the data estimated by the methods are compatible, representing the accuracy of the results. Concerning the figure, it is obvious that by the incorporation of the nano-particles into the Nimatrix, its corrosion current density is significantly reduced (by one-fifth of its initial value), indicating the positive effect of the nano-particles in the corrosion reduction. Indeed, by the incorporation of the nano-particles, the Ni crystal structure is modified and its crystallite size is refined considerably, thereby improving the coating corrosion resistance [36]. As can be seen, in the composite coatings, by increasing the nano-particles concentration in the electrodeposition bath, the corrosion current density decreases noticeably, reaches its minimum value (1.06 µA/cm 2 ) at 20 g/L and then re-increases (e.g. 4.29 µA/cm 2 for 40 g/L). Since the dense, uniform, and defect-free coating is attained at the moderate concentration of the reinforcement (e.g. 20 g/L) in the electrolyte bath, the coating shows the highest corrosion resistance amongst the
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
composite coatings. As mentioned above, at the low nano-particles concentrations, the coating contains a high density of micro-cracks (Fig. 1 (a)); also, a high level of micro-pores (Fig. 1 (c)) appears in the coating deposited at the high concentration of the nano-particles in the bath. That is, at the low and high reinforcement concentrations, the steel substrate can be exposed to the corrosion media, creating a galvanic coupling between the coating and the substrate and thereby altering the corrosion current density.

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Passivation Behavior
sections.text:
Fig. 9 depicts the cyclic polarization results of the deposited coatings at different nano-particle concentrations in the electrodeposition bath. As it is evident, by increasing the particle fraction in the bath, the passivation behavior of the coatings is altered significantly, wherein the best passivation behavior can be seen in the coating deposited from the electrolyte with the concentration of 20 g/L Al2O3+SiC nano-particles. Comparing the forward and reverse polarization curves of Fig. 9 indicates that in the forward cycle, a relatively high critical current density is required to passivate the coatings and the passivation potential is considerably high and consequently the passive range is relatively small. While in the reverse cycle the passive potential range is significantly high since the coatings are previously passivated in the forward cycle. That is, the coatings are good candidates for the corrosion protection of the steel surfaces for industrial applications, provided that the passivation treatment was conducted on the coating surface prior to use. Table 3 lists the passivation parameters of the prepared coatings extracted from the cyclic polarization results of Fig. 9. According to the results, the breakdown potential in the coatings is relatively compatible and the re-passivation potential is almost close to the breakdown potential, revealing the high resistance of the prepared coatings to pitting corrosion in
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
the present environment. However, the re-passivation potential of the 5 g/L and 40 g/L coatings is remarkably reduced, revealing the less resistance of the coatings to the pit propagation phenomenon. Comparing the passive range of the coatings indicates that by increasing the nanoparticles concentration in the bath, it initially is decreased, then enhanced, and finally reduced once again. The inverse manner appears in the variation of the passive current density. A wide passive region (0.92 V) and a small passive current density are achieved for the coatings deposited from the electrolyte bath containing the optimum concentration of the nano-particles (20 g/L). Indeed, by the nano-particles incorporation, several micro-galvanic cells can be formed on the coating surface, accelerating the passivation process of the metal matrix and reducing the passivation potential and consequently increasing the passive range [50]. At the nano-particles concentrations significantly far from the optimum concentration (20 g/L), due to the existence of microstructural defects (e.g. micro-cracks and micro-holes), the passive range is reduced markedly, the current density in the passive region increases substantially and the re-passivation potential decreases meaningfully.

sections.heading: 3.4.4. EIS Studies
sections.text:
To further investigate the corrosion activities of the deposited coatings, they were studied by EIS. Fig. 10 demonstrates the Nyquist spectra of the pure Ni and selected nanocomposite coatings (10 g/L, 20 g/L, and 40 g/L) in the acidic 0.5 M Na2SO4 solution (pH=2). Concerning the results, it can be seen that only one capacitance loop appears in the plot of the pure nickel and nano-composite coatings. Moreover, in all of the composite coatings, the semicircles diameters are much larger than that of the pure Ni, confirming the polarization results. Two different equivalent circuits (Fig. 11), which are generally proposed for the analysis of the EIS results of
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
metal matrix composite coatings, were adopted to fit the impedance spectra by using IviumSoft 2.231 software. For a better quality fit, the capacitance was substituted with a constant phase element (CPE, Q), accounting for the deviation from the ideal dielectric behavior and for the existing inhomogeneity and surface roughness [51, 52]. In Fig. 11, Re is the resistance of the solution, Qdl is linked to the double layer capacitance, Rct is the charge transfer resistance, Rcoat is the coating resistance which reflects the coating ability to hinder the electrolyte penetration from its surface to the substrate/coating interface [53-55], and Qcoat is the capacitance of the deposited coating which can be considerably altered by electrolyte penetration into the coating [53-55]. The R and Q parameters of the produced coatings are listed in Table 4. The simulated curves associated with the first equivalent circuit (simple RC model, Fig. 11 a) were well fitted with the experimental results of the pure Ni coating and 20 g/L nanocomposite coatings. Table 4 lists the circuit parameters of the produced pure nickel and nanocomposite coatings. It shows that the resistance of the 20 g/L coating is significantly higher and its capacitance is lower than that of the pure Ni, revealing higher corrosion resistance of the produced 20 g/L nanocomposite coating. In the case of 10 g/L and 40 g/L coatings, the 2 RC model (Fig. 11 b) was well fitted with the experimental results. The resistance of these coatings is higher and their capacitance is lower than that of the pure Ni. However, as previously mentioned, at the low and high quantities of the nanoparticles in the electrolyte bath, the coating contains a high proportion of micro-crack and/or micro-pores, which can comprehensively reduce the protective ability of the coating. During 1 h of immersion in the Na2SO4 solutions prior to the EIS tests, the corrosive environment can be penetrated through the coating at the substrate/coating interface, causing the substrate corrosion at the exposed area. Fig. 12 indicates the Bode plot of the selected deposits. According to Fig. 12 a, the maximum value of the total impedance (Z) at all frequency ranges corresponds to the 20
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
g/L Al2O3+SiC nanocomposite coating, implying the best corrosion behavior of this coating. Also, the variation of the phase angle versus frequency (Fig. 12 b) shows one time constants for the pure Ni and 20g/L and two time constants for the 10 g/L and 40 g/L deposits, which is compatible with the Nyquist results interpretations.
It is found that among the deposited coatings which are examined by the EIS method, the 20
g/L nanocomposite coating is the best barrier layer to protect the steel substrate against corrosion after 1 h of immersion in the acidic Na2SO4 solution. This is manifested from the best fitting of its EIS result with the simple RC model, the maximum resistance, minimum capacitance, and maximum impedance (Z) value of this coating, as well as the appearance of one relaxation time in its bode plot.
The corrosion behavior of the produced Ni/Al2O3+SiC, Ni/Al2O3, and Ni/SiC nano-
composites coatings (20 g/L) is compared in Table 5. Four important corrosion parameters, including (1) corrosion potential, (2) corrosion current density, (3) breakdown potential, and (4) passivation range in the 0.5 M acidic Na2SO4 were compared. Also the deposition conditions, microhardness values, and wear rates of the deposits were reported. With respect to the results, it is clear that the corrosion behavior of the produced Ni/Al2O3+SiC nanocomposite coating is better than that of the Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiC coating. The higher corrosion potential, lower corrosion current density, and developed passivation range of the Ni/Al2O3+SiC coating compared to those of the Ni/SiC and Ni/Al2O3 are typical. Also, the high volume fraction of the deposited Al2O3+SiC and the high microhardness and low wear rate of the Ni/Al2O3+SiC coating reveal the effectiveness of the coating procedure. That is, with respect to the Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiC nanocomposite coatings, the properties improvement of the Ni coating by incorporation of both Al2O3 and SiC nanoparticles is distinctive.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, the effect of the concentration of Al2O3-SiC nano-particles in the electrolyte bath on the corrosion resistance, passivation behavior, structure, micro-hardness, and wear resistance of the electro-co-deposited Ni matrix composite coatings was investigated. Based on the results, it can be inferred that: 1) By Al2O3+SiC co-deposition, the Ni crystallite size was reduced up to 58% and its crystallographic texture changed from (100) to (111), which contributed to the micro-hardness and wear resistance enhancements. 2) By the nanoparticles incorporation, the wear mechanism changed from adhesive to abrasive. Also, the friction coefficient of the produced composite coatings was increased considerably by the particle addition to the electrolyte bath. 3) By the nano-particles incorporation, the corrosion potential of the coating was initially reduced from -0.19 V (pure Ni) to -0.22 V (5 g/L nanoparticles in bath). Then, it returned to noble directions and reached its maximum value (-0.13 V) at the 20 g/L Al2O3+SiC in the bath. Finally, it moved again to the active directions (e.g. -0.26 V at 40 g/L). 4) All of the produced nanocomposite coatings indicated a better corrosion current density than the pure Ni coating. The minimum value of the corrosion rate was observed for the coating deposited in the bath containing 20 g/L Al2O3+SiC nanoparticles, which was one-fifth of the pure Ni corrosion rate. 5) A wide passive region (0.92 V) and a small passive current density were achieved for the coatings deposited from the electrolyte bath containing the optimum concentration of the nanoparticles (20 g/L). At the nano-particles concentrations considerably far from the optimum
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U

concentration, the passive range was reduced markedly, the current density in the passive region was increased substantially and the re-passivation potential was decreased meaningfully. 6) The breakdown potential of the produced coatings was relatively compatible and the repassivation potential was close to the breakdown potential, revealing the high resistance of the coatings to pitting corrosion propagation in the present environment. 7) Amongst the produced coatings, the 20 g/L nanocomposite coating indicated the maximum resistance, minimum capacitance, and maximum impedance value, displaying the best barrier layer to protect the steel substrate against corrosion. 8) The best corrosion resistance and passivation behavior, and the maximum microhardness were achieved by electro-co-deposition of 20 g/L Al2O3+SiC addition to the commercial watts bath of Ni deposition. 9) The corrosion and passivation results of the produced nanocomposite coating with the optimum amount of Al2O3+SiC in the bath (20 g/L) is considerably better than those of the NiAl2O3 and Ni/SiC results, revealing the beneficial effect of the incorporation of both Al2O3 and SiC to the Ni matrix. 10) The Al2O3+SiC nanocomposite coatings are good candidates for corrosion protection of steel surfaces for industrial applications, provided that the amount of nano-particles added to the electrodeposition bath was accurately controlled and a passivation treatment is carried out on the deposit surface prior to use.

Indeed, by the nano-particles incorporation, several micro-galvanic cells can be formed on the coating surface, accelerating the passivation process of the metal matrix and reducing the passivation potential and consequently increasing the passive range [50].

11, Re is the resistance of the solution, Qdl is linked to the double layer capacitance, Rct is the charge transfer resistance, Rcoat is the coating resistance which reflects the coating ability to hinder the electrolyte penetration from its surface to the substrate/coating interface [53-55], and Qcoat is the capacitance of the deposited coating which can be considerably altered by electrolyte penetration into the coating [53-55].

metadata.abstractText: The effect of the concentration of Al2O3-SiC nano-particles in an electrolyte bath on the structure, micro-hardness, wear resistance, corrosion performance, and passivation behavior of electro-co-deposited Ni-matrix composite coatings was investigated. Structure and texture studies were done by X-ray diffraction. The Vickers micro-hardness and wear resistance of the produced nano-composite coatings were evaluated and compared with the results of the pure Ni coating. The corrosion and passivation behaviors of the prepared coatings were investigated in an acidic 0.5 M Na2SO4 solution by a potentiostat-galvanostat device. It was found that by the nanoparticle incorporation, the crystallographic texture of the Ni-matrix changes and the Ni crystallite size is considerably reduced to the nano-metric range. It was also realized that the microhardness, wear resistance, corrosion performance, and passivation behaviors of the coatings are significantly improved by the incorporation of the Al2O3 and SiC nano-particles into the Nimatrix, provided that the optimum concentration of the nano-particles is utilized in the electrolyte bath. * Corresponding author.
